docs.lead_paragraph: ALMOST every working parent has faced the task of finding emergency child care. Marcia C. Inhorn remembers all too vividly the quandary she faced six years ago, when her son, then 13 months old, came down with chickenpox.

headline.main: Personal Business; The Nanny Is Late. You Have a Speech. What Now?

docs.lead_paragraph: ON March 12, a Texas jury chose to disregard Andrea Yates's assertion of the role of mental illness when she took the lives of her five children. That same day, the authorities say, the delusions of a Long Island man -- Peter Troy -- commanded him to commit two heinous murders in a Lynbrook church.
docs.abstract: Michael Stoltz essay on murder cases involving Andrea Yates in Texas and Peter Troy on Long Island focuses on what steps he believes society can take to prevent such incidents; holds people do recover from mental illness, people with serious mental illness rarely commit violence against others and America needs to treat mental illness same way as other diseases (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE numbers may not lie, the people who crunch them sure do. It's harder than it looks. So one job sector keeps growing even as unemployment rises. In an age of accounting scandals, number-crunchers are needed more than ever. Just look at this sampling of recent classified ads: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER. M.B.A., C.P.A. Must be able to report one earnings figure while simultaneously looking at another; massage numbers; lobby; move debt off books; rally stockholders; defer income to a later quarter till the end of time. Ability to name holding companies after birds of prey and action figures a plus. Should be on intimate terms with at least one cabinet member, reachable in one phone call or less and known to you as ''sweetie.'' 5-10 yrs. experience in keeping two sets of books.
docs.abstract: Jenny Lyn Bader comment imagines 'classified ads' for executives, analysts and others in ethically-challenged time (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Breast cancer diagnosis is in the domain of both medicine and politics. While the scientific issues belong properly within medicine, the accessibility issues [''The Wait for Breast X-Rays Grows Longer,'' April 21] are rightfully political. Mammography needs to be more accessible and available for it to be effective in the early diagnosis of breast cancer. But recent actions by insurance companies make access to mammography more difficult by limiting their insured to using only specific sites. This needs corrective legislation. As a diagnostic radiologist who has been involved in all aspects of breast cancer diagnosis for more than 30 years, I also think it is irresponsible to recommend that every questionable area should undergo biopsy. The lawyer who was quoted should not be setting the standard that we must follow or risk facing him in court, rather than in a medical scientific venue. HARVEY LEFKOWITZ, M.D. Plainview

headline.main: Doing Mammograms In a Responsible Manner

docs.abstract: Dr Harvey Lefkowitz letter on April 21 article holds legislation is needed to make sure insurance companies do not limit access to mammography

docs.lead_paragraph: Marc L. Miringoff, the director of the Fordham University Institute for Innovation in Social Policy and a longtime champion of social reform, had been hoping to fly below the radar of national politics by producing a report called ''The Social Health of the States.'' But when the results of the research came back, the map of the United States that it produced looked almost exactly like the electoral map most Americans stared at on election night in November 2000. Eighteen of the 20 states with the worst records on social health, as measured by standards like infant mortality and high school completion rates, were in the South, West and Southwest and had cast their electoral votes for President Bush. Eighteen of the 20 states with the best scores on social health, most in the Northeast and the Midwest, had voted for Al Gore.

headline.main: With the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, a Social Report Card

docs.abstract: Marc L Miringoff, director of Fordham University Institute for Innovation in Social Policy, develops state-by-state index for measuring health of country by specific indicators of social and economic conditions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans said today that they were drafting legislation to slow the growth in Medicare payments to hospitals and had discussed the idea of charging elderly people a modest co-payment for the use of home health care services. Home care is one of the few services for which no co-payment is now charged.

headline.main: House G.O.P. Seeking Ways to Slow Growth of Hospital Outlays Under Medicare

docs.abstract: House Republicans are drafting bill to slow growth in Medicare payments to hospitals; say they are discussing idea of charging elderly people modest co-payment for use of home health care services, one of few services for which co-payment is not charged; centerpiece of bill is proposal to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare; as corollary, House Republicans plan to alter formulas for paying hospitals, doctors, nursing homes, home health agencies and health maintenance organizations, all of which are lobbying for more money; White House officials insist that changes must not produce net increase in Medicare spending beyond what is envisioned under existing law; many lawmakers say top priority is to increase Medicare payments to doctors, some of whom are refusing to take new Medicare patients; doctors' Medicare payments were cut by 5.4 percent this year under law that will further reduce fees paid for physician service in each of next three years, for total decreases of 17 percent by 2005 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines and Union Reach Tentative Agreement United Airlines and a union representing more than 23,000 ground workers reached a tentative agreement on a contract that would increase the workers' pay above 1994 levels, making the wages the highest in the industry. If ratified, the agreement, two years in the making, will pave the way for United executives to talk to union leaders about wage concessions in an effort to return the company to profitability. [Page C7.] Disney Operating Income Falls 32% Walt Disney reported net income of $259 million, compared with a loss of $567 million in the period a year earlier. That loss was the result primarily of a $1 billion charge. Operating income at four main segments fell 32 percent because of ratings weaknesses at ABC and a soft advertising environment. [C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna reported a turnaround in its troubled health insurance business yesterday, reflecting sharply higher premiums and the loss of millions of members that it said had been money losers. Aetna shares rose $5.93, or 13.5 percent, to $49.91, leading a surge in health insurer stocks.

headline.main: Aetna Health Care Unit Posts A Profit, Ending Its Drought

docs.abstract: Aetna says operating profits in first quarter were $64.9 million compared with loss of $84.6 million year earlier; revenue was $5.26 billion, down 18 percent from $6.43 billion in 2001 quarter; says health insurance premiums will rise 18 percent this year, ahead of medical costs, which are expected to grow 15 to 16 percent; chief executive Dr John W Rowe comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate passed a stripped-down energy bill today that would produce little new fuel for Americans and do little to conserve existing resources. The measure has a variety of new rules and small tax breaks that its sponsors say could encourage the development of energy sources like wind power, solar power and ethanol and lead to more efficient use of fuel in some areas.

headline.main: Senate Passes An Energy Bill Called Flawed By Both Sides

docs.abstract: Senate passes stripped-down energy bill that would produce little new fuel for Americans and do little to conserve existing resources; measure has variety of new rules and small tax breaks that its sponsors say could encourage development of alternative energy sources and lead to more efficient use of fuel; bill now goes to conference committee for reconciliation with bill backed by Bush administration, which House passed last year; House and Senate versions compared; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, the government will release figures expected to show that the economy came roaring back in the first three months of this year, bringing a curtain down on the recession and giving cause for optimism to workers, businesses and investors. But for President Bush, who distanced himself from the weak economy even before taking office and has since avoided blame for the rise in unemployment, the good news presents a quandary.

headline.main: Washington Memo; Economic Revival Poses a Problem for Bush

docs.abstract: Government is set to release figures expected to show that the economy came roaring back in first three months of this year, ending recession and giving cause for optimism; but Pres Bush faces quandary over how to respond to good news, since he has distanced himself from weak economy and avoided taking blame (Washington Memo) (M)
